stem: The nurse is performing a focused cardiovascular assessment. Place the assessment steps in the correct order of performance.

options.text: Auscultate for heart sounds (S1, S2) and murmurs.
Inspect the chest wall for pulsations, heaves, or symmetry.
Palpate the apical pulse (PMI) and check for thrills.
Document the findings and report abnormalities.

rationale.correct: Standard assessment sequence for all systems except the abdomen is Inspection, Palpation, Percussion (if applicable), and Auscultation. (1) Look first to avoid altering findings. (2) Touch next to confirm visual cues. (3) Listen for 'internal' data. (4) Record the results.
rationale.incorrect: Auscultating before inspection is non-standard and may lead to missing visual physical findings like JVD or edema.
clinicalPearls: The apical pulse should be palpated at the 5th intercostal space, mid-clavicular line. Thrills (vibrations) indicate severe murmurs.

questionTrap.howToOvercome: Remember that for the ABDOMEN, the order is I-A-P-P (Inspect, Auscultate, Palpate, Percuss) so you don't stimulate bowel sounds by touching first. For everything else, touch before you listen.

mnemonic.title: I-P-P-A
mnemonic.expansion: Inspect, Palpate, Percuss, Auscultate (The standard sequence).

reviewUnits.heading: Physical Examination Techniques
reviewUnits.body: Nurses must perform assessments in a quiet environment and follow a systematic head-to-toe or system-based approach to ensure no area is missed.
